The Titles between the 9th and the 15th have a nearer relation to Procedure proper than the other parts 01 this Book, and are all closely modelled after Gaius. The first of them deals, though some· what uninstructively, with the employrnent of agents or attorneys in litigation, which, originally tolerated only in very few cases, had, as Jusfinian remarks, become almost universally permissible under the later practice.
